weeklyTopNews.title: Federal Government offers $130b in coronavirus wage subsidies for businesses to pay workers
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Government expects up to 6 million people will access a $1,500 fortnightly wage subsidy. The so-called JobKeeper payment is designed to keep people in work. The Government will also lift the means-testing threshold for the partners of JobSeeker recipients.

weeklyTopNews.title: JobKeeper Payment questions: Here is exactly who is eligible
weeklyTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison announced a new wage subsidy package: a $1500 fortnightly sum now known as the "JobKeeper Payment"

weeklyTopNews.title: Private hospitals to free up thousands of beds in deal with Federal Government to tackle coronavirus
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Federal Government has struck a deal with the country's 657 private hospitals, giving the Commonwealth access to another 34,000 hospital beds to help tackle the coronavirus crisis. The Commonwealth will guarantee the survival of private hospitals during this period while elective surgery, which is their main form of income, is cancelled.

weeklyTopNews.title: Gatherings restricted to two people to slow spread of coronavirus
weeklyTopNews.summary: As of Midnight March 30, the previous gathering limit of 10 people has been cut to two. Like the old restrictions, the new limit does not apply to people who live together. Weddings are still capped at five people and funerals at 10. Vulnerable people have been advised to stay home.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus update Australia: Scott Morrison announces strictest gathering measures yet
weeklyTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced the strictest gathering recommendations to date - that no more than two people gather in public spaces at any given time. This move also spells the closure for public areas, such as playgrounds, outdoor gyms and skate parks, though restrictions on weddings and funerals will stay the same.

weeklyTopNews.title: Federal Government launches Coronavirus Australia app and WhatsApp feature
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Coronavirus Australia app allows users to navigate the latest advice and information about coronavirus. In addition to the new features, the Federal Government also detailed its $1.1 billion healthcare package.

weeklyTopNews.title: Health Minister Greg Hunt says there are early signs that Australia is flattening the curve, even though coronavirus cases are still on the rise.
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Federal Government said the rate of increase of cases was about 25-30 per cent a day last week, which has fallen to about 13-15 per cent this weekend. However, they warn that Australians must continue to follow social distancing and self-isolation guidelines.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus patients’ average age only 48 as Australian tally soars beyond 3,400
weeklyTopNews.summary: There are now 3,400 cases of the virus in Australia, a vast majority of which have been diagnosed in New South Wales and Victoria. The median age of Australians diagnosed with novel coronavirus has been revealed to be 48 years old. However, the average age of fatalities is 77.

weeklyTopNews.title: Global economy is in recession: IMF head
weeklyTopNews.summary: The head of the International Monetary Fund says it is clear that the global economy has now entered a recession that could be as bad or worse than the 2009 downturn. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva forecasted a recovery in 2021, but she said this would only occur if countries succeed in containing the coronavirus and limiting the economic damage.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus in Australia: Army called in to help enforce strict new quarantine rules
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Australian Army will be deployed across all states and territories, stepping in to assist governments with new measures. The ADF will assist in both monitoring Friday’s regulations for returned overseas travellers and ensuring compliance checks with those in self-isolation at their homes. However, the prime minister says the army will not have the power to prosecute or arrest.

weeklyTopNews.title: No national decision on school closures over coronavirus, PM says states must decide
weeklyTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced that the decision on whether to close schools before the end of term will be up to each state premier. He also stated that over the next few weeks, the schools themselves will be preparing, on a national basis, to get some consistency about when schools will reopen on the other side of school holidays.

weeklyTopNews.title: International travellers returning to Australia to be sent to quarantine facilities for two weeks
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australians returning from international travel will be quarantined in hotels and other accommodation facilities for two weeks before being allowed to go home, under new measures to control the spread of coronavirus. The measure will affect all international travellers returning after midnight on Saturday 28th of March.

weeklyTopNews.title: Jobless queues to grow amid virus shutdown
weeklyTopNews.summary: Thousands of people have been queuing at Centrelink offices as tighter restrictions on businesses, community facilities and public spaces came into effect, causing many people to lose their jobs. Economists predict 814,000 Australians will be added to dole queues before the end of June. Centrelink is rapidly recruiting an extra 5000 staff to deal with the influx of demand.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus jobs fallout: at least 35,000 workers stood down in three days as businesses reel
weeklyTopNews.summary: At least 35,000 people have been put out of work in just three days by casinos, airlines, retailers and other businesses that have stood down their workers in response to the coronavirus crisis. Westpac’s chief economist, Bill Evans, said the coronavirus crisis would cost 814,000 jobs by June, more than doubling the unemployment rate to 11.1%.
